Figura 8.13 – Comparação entre os registros isotópicos de ? 18
O de espeleotemas do centro leste do Brasil, cavernas Lapa Grande e Lapa Sem Fim (presente trabalho) e nordeste, região da
Chapada Diamantina, Gruta Marota (Barreto, 2010), com a série isotópica de ? 18
O do testemunho de gelo da Groenlândia NGRIP (em preto)( North Greenland Ice Core Project members, 2004).A barra de erro em preto determina a idade e o erro da datação de amostra de crosta de calcita subaquática coletada na Lapa Grande. A barra em azul indica excursão isotópica associada com o período de deposição da camada de IRD H4.
Quando comparados com as variações de temperatura atmosférica do Hemisfério
norte, os registros isotópicos da Lapa Grande e Lapa Sem Fim apresentam um acoplamento
notável com a variabilidade climática dos eventos de escala milenar identificados nos
testemunhos de gelo (Figura 8.13). A amplitude das excursões isotópicas registradas na escala
milenar (> 3 ‰) sugere que as chuvas de monções da região centro-leste do Brasil
experimentaram variações substancias no curso dos eventos GS e GI bem como durante os
eventos HS (Figura 8.13). O impacto dos eventos milenares no regime hidrológico das regiões
centro-leste e nordeste também pôde ser evidenciado nas flutuações regionais do freático,
registradas na forma de marquises carbonáticas e crostas de calcita subaquática depositadas
ao longo de conduto vadoso da Lapa Grande. Atualmente o conduto principal da Lapa Grande
encontra-se permanente seco. Entretanto, fases pretéritas de inundação e agradação
sedimentar na caverna são evidenciadas por represas de travertinos de grande porte,
sedimentação clástica fina no piso da caverna e a ocorrência de crostas de calcita subaquática
junto às paredes do conduto. Para determinar ao menos a idade de uma das fases de ativação
do conduto, foi coletada uma amostra de calcita subaquática depositada junto à parede do
Discussão 158
conduto principal a aproximadamente 1 m de altura do piso da caverna (Figura 8.14). A
amostra, datada pelo método U/Th, apresenta idade de 35.9 ± 1.2 mil anos AP (Figura 8.14).
Figura 8.14 – Imagem da crosta da calcita subaquática depositada na rocha encaixante da parede do conduto principal da Lapa Grande.
Apesar do erro elevado da datação da amostra (35.9 ± 1.2), o intervalo de formação da
crosta de calcita subaquática é coerente com o intervalo do GS8, entre 36.53 – 35.43 mil anos
AP, e sugere que sua formação tem relação com a elevação do freático no conduto em
resposta à intensificação do SMSA como registrado nas estalagmites da Lapa Sem Fim (Figura
8.13). De modo semelhante, evidencias de fases úmidas no período que abrange o Último
Máximo Glacial e o evento Heinrich Stadial 1 (HS1) foram sugeridas em estudos prévios
baseados na datação de travertinos do rio Salitre no norte da Bahia e na ocorrência associada
de macrofósseis de folhas de espécies de plantas comuns a Mata Atlântica e Amazônia (Auler
& Smart 2001; Cristalli, 2006; Auler et al., 2004). A ocorrência abundante dos macrofósseis
vegetais em tufas carbonáticas depositadas às margens do rio Salitre sugerem condições de
alta umidade, atribuídas à expansão de florestas úmidas para a região hoje ocupada pela
Caatinga durante eventos milenares frios durante a última Glaciação (Cristalli, 2006).
Na Figura 8.15 a reconstituição da paleopluviosidade região centro-leste do Brasil é
comparada com registros paleoclimáticos relacionados às variações de temperatura da
atmosfera e da intensidade dos ventos das regiões de altas latitudes do Hemisfério norte
(North Greenland Ice Core Project members, 2004), variações de TSM das regiões de médias
latitudes do Atlântico Norte (Salgueiro et al., 2010) e, por fim, com as chuvas de monções no
norte da Venezuela (Deplazes et al., 2013). Ainda, com o objetivo de avaliar as variações
durante os eventos de deposição das camadas Heinrich, o registro é apresentado em janelas
Discussão 159
temporais de aproximadamente 10 mil anos, contemporâneas aos eventos HS1, HS2, HS4 e
HS5 (Figura 8.15).
Se, por um lado, a definição dos eventos GS e GI é clara e objetiva no registro
paleoclimático, assim determinada pelas variações de ? 18
O e Ca 2+
nos testemunhos de gelo da
Groenlândia (Rasmussen et al., 2014), a definição dos eventos HS pode ser um tanto quanto
subjetiva. Os eventos HS derivam das camadas Heinrich, relacionadas à deposição de IRD no
Atlântico Norte atribuídas a eventos de massiva incursão de icebergs contemporâneas aos
eventos GS (Hemming, 2004). Durante a deposição de uma camada Heinrich, foram
registradas grandes excursões negativas de TSM nas regiões de médias e altas latitudes do
Atlântico Norte (Bard et al., 2000; Salgueiro et al., 2010). Há, neste sentido, o entendimento de
que um evento Heinrich não deve restringir-se apenas ao pico de deposição de IRD, e sim, de
um modo mais amplo, define um período de anomalias de temperaturas ocorridas durante os
eventos GS (Rahmstorf, 2002; McManus et al., 2004; Stanford et al., 2011; Eynaud et al., 2012;
Sanchez-Goñi & Harrison, 2010). Entretanto, nem sempre os eventos de deposição das
camadas Heinrich e as anomalias negativas de TSM associadas encontram correspondências
com as variações de temperatura registradas durante os eventos GS. Como pode ser
observado na Figura 8.15, a deposição das camadas H1 e H2 não encontram correspondência
com variações nos registros de ? 18
O e Ca 2+
dos testemunhos de gelo, o que sugere que as
variações climáticas relativas aos eventos Heinrich concentram-se nas zonas de médias e
baixas latitudes. Podemos então definir como um evento HS (i.e. Heinrich Stadial) a anomalia
de temperatura de TSM onde uma camada Heinrich está contida.
Ao se observar com detalhe os gráficos da Figura 8.15 nota-se que, durante os eventos
de deposição de IRD, as curvas isotópicas das estalagmites da região centro-leste do Brasil
registram excursões isotópicas significativas e de caráter igualmente abrupto. Durante o
evento GS5, por exemplo, é possível notar no registro isotópico da estalagmite LG12, uma
breve e abrupta excursão negativa de ? 18
O (Figura 8.15). Considerando os desalinhamentos
cronológicos decorrente das incertezas nas datações de 14
C dos registros marinhos, é possível
atribuir a essa excursão o evento deposicional H5. Igualmente, se observarmos o período do
evento deposicional das camadas H4 e H2, quando as datações 14
C adquirem maior precisão,
notamos uma relação coerente entre perturbações abruptas de TSM e picos deposicionais de
IRD no Atlântico norte com variações de ? 18
O em estalagmites da Lapa Sem Fim (Figura 8.15).
O bom acoplamento do SMSA aos eventos GS e GI é explicado pelo deslocamento
latitudinal da ZCIT em resposta às mudanças do gradiente inter-hemisférico de TSM do
Atlântico Norte durante esses eventos (Chiang & Bitz, 2005; Cvijanivic & Chiang, 2013).
Discussão 160
Durante os eventos HS e GS, a progressão das anomalias negativas de TSM e o fortalecimentos
dos alísios de NE, associados com a intensificação da alta dos açores, são as principais feições
da dinâmica climática que seriam responsáveis pelo deslocamento para sul da ZCIT e,
consequentemente, intensificação do SMSA. Por outro lado, a intensidade e o posicionamento
médio da ZCAS é muito sensível a atividade convectiva na Bacia Amazônica (Vera et al., 2006;
Carvalho et al., 2004; Marengo et al., 2012). A relação entre esses sistemas convectivos em
escala milenar pode ser discutida com base na associação entre as reconstituições da
paleoprecipitação da região centro-leste do Brasil com as chuvas de monções próximas ao
Caribe, na costa da Venezuela (Figura 8.15). A partir dessa comparação de registros
paleoclimáticos, é possível deduzir que as camadas Heinrich pode ter relação com um
incremento no deslocamento meridional da ZCIT, além do já causado pelas anomalias
climáticas durante um evento estadial ou HS. Contudo, ao olharmos para o registro de
paleoprecipitação da Bacia de Cariaco, durante os períodos da deposição das camadas H1, H5
e H4, não notamos a estrutura interna das anomalias associadas aos eventos picos de IRD das
camadas Heinrich (Deplazes et al., 2013).
O registro dos sedimentos da Bacia de Cariaco apresentado por Deplazes et al. (2013)
utiliza o índice de reflectância associado a coloração do sedimento marinho como indicador
das variações relativas entre as contribuições de sedimentos terrígenos (principalmente
silicatos) e biogênicas (essencialmente carbonatos). Sedimentos mais escuros indicam maior
aporte terrígeno e estão relacionados ao aumento das precipitações no continente durante o
deslocamento para norte da ZCIT, no verão boreal. Já, os sedimentos mais claros indicam
maior contribuição de fonte biogênica associada à ocorrência de foraminíferos e, são
atribuídos a maior produtividade biológica na Bacia, decorrente do aumento da ressurgência
próximo a costa. Esse fenômeno tem relação com o deslocamento mais à sul da ZCIT e a
intensificação dos ventos alísios de NE (Haug et al., 2001). De acordo com Deplazes et al.
(2013) os eventos GS são caracterizados pela ausência da contribuição terrígena na bacia, o
que indicaria um posicionamento permanentemente a sul de 10°N da ZCIT durante esses
períodos. Sendo assim, o registro de Cariaco não teria capacidade de registrar anomalias
relativas às camadas Heinrich, uma vez que esses eventos ocorrem durante os GS. No Anexo IV
é apresentado um modelo de artigo para publicação relativa ao impacto dos eventos milenares
no SMSA. Em adição, esta temática é abordada em detalhe na discussão da estrutura interna e
cronologia das oscilações climáticas durante o HS1 em artigo recém publicado na revista
Geophysical Research Letter por Stríkis et al. (2015).

Considerações Finais 162
9. Considerações Finais
Os resultados obtidos a partir das análises isotópicas de ? 18
O de espeleotemas da
região centro-leste do Brasil representam uma importante contribuição na compreensão da
variabilidade climática do sistema de monções Sul-americano (SMSA) frente às forçantes
climáticas de escala orbital e da circulação oceânica durante o último período glacial. A partir
dos registros isotópicos de espeleotemas das cavernas Lapa Grande e Lapa Sem Fim foi
possível constatar que, durante o último glacial e Holoceno, a forçante de insolação exerceu
um papel secundário na modulação de paleoprecipitação do SMSA, com período de
acoplamento restrito ao intervalo entre 60 e 85 mil anos AP. O comportamento é contrastante
com o observado em registros do nordeste do Brasil e oeste da Bacia Amazônica, onde as fases
de desacoplamento são mais restritas ao Estágio Marinho Isotópico 3 ( 27-60 mil anos AP). A
fraca relação entre a variabilidade do regime de precipitação de monção da região centro-leste
do Brasil e a forçante de insolação foi atribuída a uma provável influência das condições de
contorno do clima no período glacial com a intensidade e posicionamento da ZCAS. Em
consequência do esfriamento do hemisfério norte, a pluviosidade no norte de Minas Gerais
esteve relativamente baixa em relação às regiões mais ao sul do Brasil. O clima
predominantemente seco na região estudada foi provavelmente causado pelo deslocamento
para SW da banda de nebulosidade com direção NW-SE que caracteriza a ZCAS.
O estudo também trouxe importantes constatações acerca da variabilidade de escala
milenar. As reconstituições da paleoprecipitação demonstraram um excelente acoplamento
das variações na intensidade do SMSA na região centro-leste do Brasil com as flutuações de
temperatura da atmosfera registrada nas regiões de altas latitudes do Atlântico Norte. Foi
observado que, durante o deglacial e, de modo mais evidente, durante o estágio Marinho
Isotópico 3, as excursões isotópicas de ? 18
O registradas nos espeleotemas da região centro-
leste do Brasil apresentaram notório acoplamento com as oscilações abruptas de temperatura
determinadas pelas transições entre os eventos estadiais (frios) e interestadiais (quentes)
registrados na estratigrafia isotópica de ? 18
O dos testemunhos de gelo da Groenlândia.
Ademais, notou-se que excursões isotópicas abruptas registradas nos espeleotemas
durante os eventos estadiais apresentam cronologia consistente com os eventos de deposição
de IRD (sigla em inglês para ice rafted debries) no Atlântico subtropical norte. A resposta do
SMSA aos curtos períodos de deposição de IRD foi relacionada com um deslocamento
adicional para sul da Zona de Convergência Intertropical (ZCIT), além do que seria imposto pelo
Considerações Finais 163
esfriamento atmosférico durante os eventos estadiais, em resposta à variação do gradiente
interhemisférico de temperatura da superfície do mar.
A investigação das oscilações climáticas revelou informações inéditas sobre a origem
eventos de pluviosidade de natureza abrupta ocorridos durante o último milênio, realizada a
partir de um registro de ? 18
O de alta resolução de uma estalagmite amostrada na caverna Lapa
dos Anjos. A reconstituição climática sugere os efeitos das forçantes radiativas associadas à
atividade solar e às erupções vulcânicas foi muito importante para origem de eventos
climáticos de grande magnitude no SMSA. O estudo detalhado da série isotópica permitiu
relacionar excursões isotópicas mais negativas de curta duração, associadas a período de
aumento regional de precipitação, com grandes erupções vulcânicas ocorridas no último
milênio. A partir da comparação com dados de deposição de sulfetos de aerossóis
vulcanogênicos registrados em testemunhos de gelo da Groenlândia e Antártica foi possível
concluir que o impacto das erupções no regime hidrológico das regiões tropicais depende do
contraste na distribuição interhemisférica de aerossóis lançados na estratosfera. O aumento
de precipitação registrado nos espeleotemas foi relacionado à redução da forçante radiativa
na região do Atlântico norte e consequente deslocamento da ZCIT pra sul, em direção ao
Hemisfério mais quente.
Por fim, O estudo de monitoramento geoquímico-isotópico nas cavernas Lapa Sem Fim
e Lapa dos Anjos avaliou que o ? 18

Study site, methods and discussion
Study site
The mean annual precipitation at the study site was estimated based on data from 8 local meteorological stations from A.D. 1936 – 2014. The rainfall dataset was obtained from the National Brazilian Meteorological Institute (Instituto Nacional de Meteorologia - INMET) website (www.inmet.gov.br) and from the Agência Nacional de Água (ANA) website (www.ana.gov.br). As each of these records are discontinuous, we applied a regional vector following the Brunet-Moret method using the software HYDRACCESS1. This method, developed by the French Institute of Research for the Development (IRD), consists in the construction of a fictive station which takes into account the gap of the records and calculates an annual index exerting a mean value equal to 1 throughout the record.
As can be observed in the Fig. S2, the maximum precipitation occurs at the peak of SAMS activity between November and February, which corresponds to 70% of the total annual precipitation. To assess
the extent of the “amount effect” in the ? 18
O of local rainfall in 2011 we initiated a monthly monitoring program of stable isotopes in precipitation near the cave site. The monitoring station is locates 4 km to the east of Lapa dos Anjos cave, and was installed in the facilities of the meteorological station of the National Brazilian Meteorological Institute (Instituto Nacional de Meteorologia - INMET) (15°26'52.99"S; 44°21'58.66"W), Januária city.
The weighted mean monthly ? 18
O recorded from the precipitations presents a strong negative correlation with the mean monthly rainfall at 99.9 % level (r = -0.92, p-value<0.001) (Fig. S3a). The
correlation between monthly rainfall amount and monthly mean ? 18
O assessed for the study site is consistent with data from IAEA-GNIP station in Brasília between 1963 to 1987 (r =- 0.82, p- value<0.001), where precipitation is climatologically identical to the study region (Fig. S3b).

Discussion
There are no clearly defined-criteria for the designation of the Little Ice Age (LIA) and the Medieval Climate Anomaly (MCA). Here we chose an objective definition for both the LIA and the MCA based on the Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction of Moberg (2). The time interval of the LIA and MCA are defined as the periods from first to last occurrence of temperature anomalies below and above one standard deviation, respectively (using the mean Northern Hemisphere temperature for the last two thousand years as a reference) (Fig. S7). The persistence of the temperature fluctuation is evaluated based upon the 30-year running mean Northern Hemisphere temperature.
This approach is particularly convenient for paleoclimate studies in tropical areas given that monsoon precipitation is sensitive to perturbations in high latitude temperature and consequent modulation of the mean position of the Intertropical Convergence Zone3,4. Following this approach, in this study the MCA is defined as period ranging from A.D. 975 to 1185 and the LIA as ranging from A.D. 1450 to 1740.

Introduction
The supporting information file contains detailed information regarding the sites description, methods and analytical procedures applied in oxygen isotope analysis of speleothems and in the biomarkers and geochemical analysis performed in the marine sediments (Figures S1 to S4). We also add information about analytical procedures related to the U-Th geochronology. The geochronological results are presented in Table S1. In addition this file presents supporting figures (S5 to S8) referred to in this discussion section of the manuscript.
Text S1.
Cave site description
Lapa Sem Fim is a cave with 21 km of planimetric development with a dominant network maze morphology. Two candle shaped stalagmites were collected: LSF3 and LSF16. The relative humidity at Lapa Sem Fim cave lies near 100% with a relatively high CO2 concentration varying from 600 to 800 ppm according to punctual measurements during field work. The present-day climate at Lapa Sem Fim and Paixão cave sites is tropical savannah-like with dry winters (Aw) and arid, steppe-like hot (BSh) respectively, according to the Köppen-Geiger classification [Peel et al., 2007].
Marine records
The upper water column at our core site is bathed by the northwestward-flowing North Brazil Current (NBC). Starting at around 10°S, the NBC originates from the South Equatorial Current (SEC), and is described as an undercurrent with a weak surface component, which intensifies further downstream [Peterson and Stramma, 1991]. Surface to thermocline conditions in the western tropical Atlantic are linked to the seasonal variability in trade wind intensity and the position of the ITCZ [Hastenrath and Merle, 1987]. The present day climate for the Acú river drainage basin varies from savannah-like with dry winter (Aw) to arid steppe-like hot (BSh) respectively, according to the Köppen-Geiger classification [Peel et al., 2007].
Text S2.
Methods
Speleothem records: oxygen isotope and geochronological records
Due to its superior geochronological control, we opted to use the LSF3 ? 18
O record to reconstruct the isotope curve for the time period between 19.4 to 17.3 kyr BP. The superior quality of the geochronological control of LSF3 when compared to LSF16 is shown in Figure S2. As is evident from Figure S2, the LSF3 stalagmite is characterized by significant changes in the stalagmite growth rates between 19.4 to 17.3 kyr BP, not seen in the LSF16 stalagmite record, due to its much lower geochronological control during this particular time period.
For the Paixão cave stalagmites the chronology is based on 11 U/Th dates: 9 for PX7 stalagmite covering a period between 15.0 to 19.2 kyr BP and 2 for PX5 stalagmite covering a period between 12.0 to 14.8 kyr BP (Figure S3). The ages were obtained by using a multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry technique (MC-ICP-MS, Thermo-Finnigan NEPTUNE) at the University of Minnesota following the procedures described by Cheng et al. [2013a]. Most dates present errors (2?)<1% (supplementary Table S1). The samples weighing between 150 and 300

Marine record: biomarkers and geochemistry
BIT index
Lipid extraction of freeze-dried powdered samples was performed with ultrasonic probes. Extracts were saponified and further separated on Bond-Elut SiO2 columns; polar fractions containing glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers (GDGTs) were eluted with 2 mL MeOH. Prior to analysis by high performance liquid chromatography / atmospheric pressure chemical ionization – mass spectrometry (HPLC/APCI-MS), samples were filtered through a 4 µm pore size PTFE filter and dissolved in hexane/isopropanol (99:1; v/v). An Agilent 1200 series HPLC/APCI-MS system equipped with a Grace Prevail Cyano column (150 mm x 2.1 mm; 3 µm) was used, and separation was achieved in normal phase using the method described by Leider et al. [2010]. GDGTs were detected by selective ion monitoring of the protonated molecular ion (M+H) peaks. Peaks with the following protonated molecular ion masses were considered: 1022 (I), 1036 (II), 1050 (III), and 1292 (crenarchaeol). The BIT index was calculated according to Hopmans et al. [2004] as
BIT = [I+II+III] / [I+III+III+crenarchaeol] (1)
Ti/Ca
Concentrations of Ti and Ca in GeoB3910-2 were determined based on ICP-OES measurements after microwave acid total digestion of freeze dried and homogenized sediments. Complete digestion of about 50 mg of sediment was achieved using a MLS ETHOS 1600 Microwave system the following quantities of acids: 3 ml HNO3, 2 ml HCl, and 0.5 ml HF. After evaporation of the acids, the residues were re-dissolved in 1 M HNO3. The accuracy of the analytical procedure was checked by processing the standard reference sediment NIST SRM 2702 every 4-5 samples. Element concentrations (Ca and Ti) were subsequently determined by ICP-OES using a Thermo Scientific IRIS Intrepid instrument. A multi-element standards solution at 5 different concentrations prepared from single element stock solutions in 1 M HNO3 was used for calibration of the measurement.
Text S3.
Results
Speleothem ? 18
O profiles
The oxygen isotopic composition of speleothem carbonate is strongly tied to the isotopic composition of the rainfall that seeps through the top of the karst aquifer [Fairchild et al., 2006]. In tropical areas deep convection and vertical uplift of air masses produces an isotopic effect known as “amount effect” [Vuille et al., 2003]. In essence, the amount
effect is the inverse proportional variation of the ? 18
O of the rainfall with the amount of precipitation [Lachniet, 2009]. At the Lapa Sem Fim cave site, an isotopic monitoring program of rainfall performed since 2011 shows that the isotopic composition of rainfall is strongly controlled by the amount-effect (Figure S1). The observed correlation (R
2 =0.73) at monthly time scales for the cave site is confirmed by the strong negative correlation between monthly
rainfall amount and monthly mean ? 18
O at the IAEA-GNIP station in Brasília between 1963 and 1987 (R 2 =0.65), where
precipitation is climatologically identical to the study region (Figure S1).
Relatively low correlation coefficients between ? 18
O and ? 13
C along the speleothem’s growth axes (Hendy test) suggest that stalagmites LSF16 (R
2 =0.24) and PX7 (R
2 =0.33) were deposited close to isotopic equilibrium. However
the Hendy test is not decisive to determinate isotopic equilibrium conditions [Mickler et al., 2004]. In further validation of the Hendy test, the good correspondence between the Lapa Sem Fim (LSF16) and Paixão (PX7) isotope
records reinforces the notion that the ? 18
O fluctuations represent information of paleoclimatic significance on a regional scale.
233 ANEXO
The ? 18
O isotope values of the Paixão cave records present clear differences in terms of their absolute values (Figure S3). In general, the stalagmites from Lapa Sem Fim cave feature values that are 2 to 3 ‰ more depleted when compared with northeastern stalagmites. The depletion is in agreement with an expected isotope effect caused by the Rayleigh distillation. The Rayleigh distillation describes the lowering of the isotope values as a consequence of the progressive condensation and removal of heavier isotopes during condensation in an air mass [Fairchild et al., 2006, Lachniet, 2009].
The amplitudes of the ? 18
O depletion within the different wet events during HS1 are equivalent between the Lapa Sem Fim and Paixão stalagmite records despite the discrepancy in absolute values (Figure S2 and S3). For instance, during the dry phase centered at 16.5 kyr B.P., both isotope records undergo an isotopic enrichment of ca. 2.3 ‰. The same holds true during the most humid event (i.e., HS1a) at 16.0 kyr B.P., when both records present an isotopic depletion of about 2.5 ‰ (Figure S2 and S3).

Abstract
Paleoclimate studies based on speleothem records suggest that variation in insolation
precession and ocean circulation plays an important role in controlling the moisture transport
along the South Atlantic Convergence Zone (SACZ), causing abrupt rainfall redistribution over
central Brazil. However, little is known about paleoclimate changes in regions directly affected
by the SACZ close to its modern axis. In this study we present a novel paleoprecipitation
reconstruction based on precisely dated ? 18
O speleothem records from central-eastern
covering the last 85 kyr. At orbital time-scale monsoon precipitation over central-eastern Brazil
shows limited coupling with insolation forcing, except for the interval between 60 and 85 kyr
BP. This feature is attributed to an additional forcing by the glacial boundary conditions that
significantly influence the position and strength of the SACZ. On the other hand, during the last
glacial, the precipitation variability over the eastern portion of the SACZ region was strongly
modulated by millennial-scale climate oscillation recorded on high latitude areas of North
Hemisphere. Particularly during the marine isotope stage 3, changes in monsoon precipitation
near the axis of SACZ mimics abrupt oscillation pacing by the transition of Greenland stadial
and interstadial events. During the wet stadial phases addition increments in the strength of
South American monsoon precipitation over central-eastern Brazil show consistent patterns in
terms of the timing and structure with the episodes of massive deposition of ice rafting debris
in the North Atlantic. Our results suggest a farther southward displacement of the Intertropical
243 ANEXO
Convergence Zone occurred as a consequence to Northern Hemisphere mid-latitude cooling
caused by the massive surging of icebergs. In this context, it is possible that the amplitude of
millennial scale paleoprecipitation variability over the SACZ region may played an important
hole on species dispersion through the forest corridors between the Amazon and Atlantic rain
forests.
Introduction
Central-eastern Brazil includes one of the most important ecotonal zones of South
America, located in the boundaries of important biomes comprehended by the
phytogeographic domains of Atlantic forest (Moist Broadleaf Forest), Cerrado (mostly savanna-
like) and Caatinga (Xeric Schrublands) (Figure 1) (Myers et al., 2000; Klink and Machado, 2004;
Santos et al., 2011; Giongo et al., 2011; Ratter et al., 1997). Vigorous episode of strengthening
in the South America Monsoon System (SAMS) during the last glacial (Wang et al., 2004; Cheng
et al., 2013a) is thought to have worked as bridge for species dispersion connecting the Moist
Broadleaf Forest biomes of the Atlantic and Amazon Forest (Costa, 2003).
The rainfall over Central-eastern Brazil is entirely modulated by the strength and
position of the South Atlantic Convergence Zone (SACZ). The SACZ is a key feature of the South
America Monsoon System (SAMS) characterized as an elongated convective band extending
from western Amazon basin to southeastern Brazil and protruding into southeastern
subtropical South Atlantic (Carvalho et al., 2004; Vera et al., 2006, Marengo et al., 2012).
Variation in the strength and position of the SACZ accounts for most of the climate variability
over SAMS domain (Carvalho et al., 2004). Given that SACZ plays a fundamental role in the
precipitation variability over tropical South America determining the patterns of variation of
the hydrologic regime over the SACZ region is of paramount importance to decipher what are
the potential driving forces capable to affect the development of biomes over tropical and
subtropical areas. However, currently paleoclimate records covering this region are sparse and
temporal fragmented. In fact, as a whole, far too little is known about the behavior of SAMS
over Central Brazil at orbital and on millennial-scale as well. In the context of the lack of
continuous and long paleoclimate record over the SACZ region here we present a novel
paleomonsoon reconstruction covering the last 85 kyr based on absolute well dated
speleothem ? 18
O record. Our results bring new assessments about the spatial pattern of
changes in the hydrologic regime of SAMS at millennial and orbital time-scale with important
implications for the reconstruction of biogeography patterns in South America.

Site description
The speleothems used in this study were collected in two distinct caves located in
central-eastern: Lapa Sem Fim (16°08’52’’S, 44°36’38’’W) and Lapa Grande (14°22’45.91”S,
44°17’19.72”W), respectively. The distance between the two caves is about 290 km (Figure 1).
The present-day climate at Lapa Sem Fim and Lapa Grande cave sites is tropical
savannah-like with dry winters (Aw) and arid, steppe-like hot (BSh) respectively, according to
the Köppen-Geiger classification (Peel et al., 2007). The annual mean precipitation of the
studied areas is around 950 mm (source: www2.ana.gov.br). The precipitation occurs almost
exclusively during the active period of the SAMS, starting in October and ending in April, with a
maximum activity between November and February that corresponds to almost 70% of total
annual precipitation (see supporting Text S1 and Figures S1). The study area is currently
occupied by the Cerrado phytogeographic domain also considered as biomes itself. The
Cerrado domain covers a vast area of central-Brazil (23% of land surface of the country) and is
dominated by semi-deciduous arboreal savanna characteristic of the Tropical/Subtropical
Grassland, Savanna and Schrublands biome with enclaves of mesophytic deciduous and semi-
245 ANEXO
deciduous forest belonging to the Tropical/Subtropical Dry Broadleaf Forest biome (Olson et
al., 2001; Coutinho et al., 2005; Klink and Machado, 2004; Ratter et al., 1997).

Results
Our record is based on a suite of 11 stalagmites belonging to Lapa Grande and Lapa
Sem Fim caves. The speleothem stable oxygen isotope (? 18
O) records from central-eastern
Brazil presented here are based on 4828 samples, yielding a mean temporal resolution of near
20 years. The chronological control of our speleothem record is based on 112 U/Th dates: 34
for stalagmite from Lapa Grande and 78 for stalagmite from Lapa Sem Fim cave. The central-
eastern Brazil speleothem record cover most portion of the last 85 kyr, presenting local hiatus,
mainly distributed along the MIS3 (Figure 2). In general, the ? 18
O values from Lapa Grande
speleothem record are around 1.5 ‰ more enriched than those from Lapa Sem Fim. Besides
the difference recorded in absolute values, as we can observe in Figures 2 both isotope record
describes consistent variations at millennial and orbital times-scale. At millennial time-scale
the isotope record is characterize by numerous oscillation of high amplitude, near 3 ‰, with
some excursion showing clear abrupt transitions recording changes up to 3.5 ‰ of magnitude
in less than 85 years. Those abrupt events are coherent to the time of Heinrich layer
depositions (Figures 3 and 4). At orbital time-scale, changes in ? 18
O records variation up to 4.6
‰, as observed between 71.5 to 62.2 kyr BP (Figure 2).

central-eastern Brazil (Figure 2). The monitoring station is precisely positioned between the

Discussion
Climate assessments
At the eastern portion of SAMS domain the role solar insolation over monsoonal
precipitation variability is complex. As we can observe in the Figure 2 during the last eighty five
thousand years monsoon precipitation over central-eastern Brazil presents locally coupling
with the solar insolation curve, restricted to the interval between 60 and 85 kyr BP. The
behavior is similar to the observed in the ? 18
O speleothem record from western Amazon basin
(Cheng et al., 2009) (Figure 2) and points to non-linear mechanism, probably dependent of
oceanic boundary conditions, connecting the strength and position of SACZ to solar insolation
forcing. More specifically, central-eastern Brazil lies in the edge of zonal circulation system,
defined as Bolivian High-Nordeste Low system (Lenters and Cook, 1997). The Bolivian High-
Nordeste Low system is an east-west upper tropospheric circulation that rises in response to
moisture convergence over the Amazon basin and the resultant large-scale subsidence over
Northeastern Brazil (Lenters and Cook, 1997; Gandu and Dias, 1998; Chen and Weng, 1999).
On orbital time-scale the Bolivian High-Nordeste Low system is known to promote an eastern-
western South Atlantic precipitation dipole (SAPD) leading to anti-phased orbital modulation
of monsoon precipitation between western Amazon and Southern Brazil with northeastern
Brazil (Cruz et al., 2009; Cheng et al., 2013a) (Figure 1). The role of the Bolivian High-Nordeste
Low system on driven precipitation variability at orbital-time scale over the studied area is also
evidenced by the zonally oriented antiphased behavior recorded between central-eastern and
247 ANEXO
western Amazon paleomonsoon reconstruction (Figure 2). Following this reasoning, the more
restrictive coupling observed between solar forcing and monsoon precipitation over central-
eastern Brazil might arise in reason of the vicinity of our study site from the SACZ axis placing
this site as a transitory region of the SAPD influence. Thus, depending on the boundary
conditions, the SACZ may act as a climate buffer barring the influence of insolation forcing over
monsoon intensity.
Nevertheless, the most noticeable feature of precipitation variability over central-
eastern Brazil occurs at millennial-scale oscillation. As demonstrated in the Figure 2, during the
last glacial the precipitation variability over the eastern portion of the SACZ region was
strongly modulated by millennial-scale climate oscillation recorded on high latitude areas of
North Hemisphere. Particularly during the Marine Isotope Stage (MIS) 3 (~27-60 kyr BP),
variations in the intensity of SACZ mimics abrupt oscillation pacing by the transitions of stadial
(cold) and interstadial (warm) events recorded in the ? 18
O isotope stratigraphy of Greenland
ice cores (North Greenland Ice Core Project members, 2004; Sanchez-Goñi and Harrison, 2010;
Rasmussen et al., 2014a) (Figures 2 and 3). The millennial-scale variability observed in the
speleothem record from Central-eastern Brazil presents a different scenario from that
recorded in the Ti/Ca of marine sediments from off northeastern Brazil (Jaeschke et al., 2007).
While the Ti/Ca record points to climate fluctuation exclusively tied to the Heinrich Stadial (HS)
events the speleothem record shows a remarkable coupling of the SAMS intensity to stadial
and interstadial events (see supporting Figures S3, S4 and Figure 3).

The high amplitude of millennial-scale ? 18
O
variability (> 3‰) points to substantial
changes in monsoon precipitation at the time of stadial-interstadial events and at the time of
Heinrich Stadial (HS) events as well (Figures 3 and S4). The impact of stadial events on the
hydrologic regime of Central-eastern Brazil is also evidenced in paleo water-table fluctuation
recorded in calcite rimes at the Lapa Grande cave walls (Figures 3 and supporting Figure S5). At
Lapa Grande cave U-Th age of a underwater carbonate coating located in edge of the cave
walls (35.87 ± 1.2 kyr BP) developed on current dry conduit points to significant increase in
ground water recharge at the epoch of Greenland Stadial 8 (36.58 – 35.48 kyr BP). Analog
oscillation in the ground-water recharge recorded over northeastern Brazil based on water-
table speleothems reinforces the imprint of cold millennial stadial events in the hydrologic
249 ANEXO
regime in the Central-eastern/Northeastern Brazil sector (Auler and Smart, 2001). Indeed,
over Central-eastern and Northeastern Brazil we frequent faced certain level of speleothem
deposition, illustrated by giant stalagmites and fossil travertines, whose occurrence witness a
more vigorous hydrological regime than today.
The good coupling between monsoon precipitation over Central-eastern and
Northeastern Brazil with North Hemisphere high latitude temperature is explained by the
latitudinal shifts in the mean position of the ITCZ as consequence of changes in the tropical
interhemispheric SST gradient (Chiang and Bitz, 2005; Cvijanivic and Chiang, 2013). The
progression of surface cooling at mid and low-latitudes during stadial and HS events are the
main causes of southward displacements of the ITCZ, whose position is dynamically
determined by the tropical interhemispheric SST gradient (Chiang and Bitz, 2005). In the same
way the strength and position of the SACZ is sensitive to the convective activity in the Amazon
basin (Vera et al., 2006; Carvalho et al., 2004; Marengo et al., 2012). This concept is reinforced
by the strike resemblance between Central-eastern Brazil paleo-monsoon reconstruction and
combined annual-resolved terrigenous input record from Cariaco basin (Deplazes et al., 2013)
and mid-latitude SST reconstruction from north Atlantic (Figure 4).

During the wet stadial phases located increments in the strength of SAMS over Central-
eastern Brazil are coherent with the episodes of massive depositional of ice rafting debris
(IRD). As we can observe in the Figure 3 and 4 a sharp increase in monsoon precipitation
characterized by a steep and brief decrease of ? 18
O, lasting less than 85 years, are frequent
recorded close to the period of Heinrich layers deposition. During the ice berg surging related
to the HS1, H2, H4 and H5 the isotope record from Central-eastern in combination with
Northeastern Brazil register negative excursion higher than 3 ‰, reaching values varying from
-7 to -9 ‰ (Figure 4). However the same does not holds to Cariaco record. As we can observed
in Figure 4, at the time of ice rafted deposition no further perturbation in monsoon
precipitation over Cariaco drainage basin can be distinguished. This assessment reinforces the
hypothesis that during stadial events, the mean position of the ITCZ was permanently
displaced southern of 10 °N in the Atlantic sector (Zarriess et al., 2011; Deplazes et al., 2013).
The uncertainties in ice core chronology derived from stratigraphic disturbances can
rich values as high 1700 years for the period of the MIS3 (Rasmussen et al., 2014b). In addition,
uncertainties in marine core chronology among, other factors, from the low temporal
resolution and large dating uncertainties of the commonly used 14C-dated records (Austin and
Hibbert, 2012) prevents to establishing a precise chronology for the timing of environmental
and climate changes between continental and marine paleoclimate archives. Thus, in face of
the strike resemblance between monsoon variability at SACZ region and North Hemisphere
high- and mid-latitude surface temperature speleothem isotope record from tropical areas
offers an alternative to ice-core chronology calibration and dating of Heinrich layers (Figures 3
and 4). In fact, atmospheric global circulation model coupled to slab ocean suggests that the
high latitude temperatures propagates into the tropics within a matter of years (Chiang and
Bitz, 2005; Cvijanovic and Chiang, 2013).

In order to better understand the main triggers of climate changes on monsoonal
precipitation over Central-eastern Brazil in Figure 4 we visually tied peaks of increase in
252 ANEXO
monsoon precipitation during stadial events recorded on Central-eastern Brazil with minor
changes terrestrial matter input recorded from Cariaco basin, synchronized with GICC05 ice
core chronology and peaks of ice rafted deposition at Iberian Margin. As we can observe in
Figure 4 in contrast to northern Atlantic mid-latitude SST and the South American monsoonal
precipitation record, over Greenland almost no significant climate perturbation is noticed
during the episodes of massive ice-rafted deposition (North Greenland Ice Core Project
members, 2004). Except for the HS2, the temperature and the strength of polar vortex remains
nearly constant whereas SST at Iberian margin and SAMS over central-eastern Brazil
underwent abrupt oscillation at millennial-scale during the events of ice berg surging. The
concordant behavior observed on both, ? 18
O and Ca 2+
record (Rasmussen et al., 2014a)
suggests a climate buffering of high latitude areas to Heinrich events, possible in reason of sea-
ice progression. Indeed in the course of MIS2, during the stadials 2 and 3 (27.73 – 14.64 kyr
BP), the atmosphere temperature over Greenland describes a quite monotonous series of
climate oscillation when compared with SST temperatures over mid-latitude areas of North
Atlantic.
Ecological insights
At the time of Younger Dryas (12.89-11.7 kyr B.P.) and HS1 events (18-14.69 kyr B.P.)
(Wang et al., 2004) travertine paleobotanical remains from Salitre river valley (10°30’ S; 40° W)
on northeastern Brazil, (~ 500 km northern from the studied site) points to the occurrence of
dense mesophytic semi-deciduous forest on current dry Caatinga forest. In the same direction,
our speleothem records points to substantial increase in monsoon at millennial time-scale
extending throughout the stadial events of the last glaciation.
The turbulent history of past rainfall variability over the SACZ region presented here
(Figures 2 and 3) supports the notion that the boundaries of biomes enclosed in the Amazon,
Cerrado, Caatinga and Atlantic forest phytogeographic domains underwent though abrupt
shifts. As demonstrated in the Figure 1 the Cerrado (savanna-like vegetation) and Caatinga
(tropical dry forest) domains acts as barriers separating the two major rain forest biomes of
Brazil depicted by the Amazon and Atlantic Forest (Costa, 2003). The strengthening in
monsoon precipitation across the SACZ during cold millennial events may have played an
important role on species dispersion through the establishment of forest corridors between
the Amazon and Atlantic rain forests. This concept is supported by the broad overlap of taxa of
mammals and amphibians from both Amazon and Atlantic forest on patches of mesophytic
forest across the biomes of Cerrado (Redford and Fonseca, 1986; Costa, 2003; Oliveira-Filho
253 ANEXO
and Ratter, 1995; Johnson et al., 1999) and in the transition zone depicted by the Tropical Dry
Broadleaf Forest (Valdujo et al., 2009). Considering their narrow habitat tolerance it is
noteworthy to account for the importance of the amphibian to the biogeography studies
whereas habitat connectivity plays an important role in regional viability of amphibian
population (Cushman, 2006).
Conclusions
Our results also have important implications for the reconstruction of biogeography
and speciation patterns in South America due to species dispersion through the forest
corridors between the Amazon and Atlantic rain forests during glacial millennial-cold events
(Wang et al., 2004), although such events of climatic changes may have displayed similar
patterns in the past far beyond our records. Substantial increases in SAMS across de SACZ
domain at the time of stadial and HS events may have conditioned the expansion of a dense
mesophytic semi-deciduous forest over a large region across Central and Northeastern Brazil,
which today is dominated by Savanna (Cerrado) and dry forest (Caatinga), connecting habitat
from the Amazon to the Atlantic rain forest.

Text S1 - Precipitation at the study site
The mean annual precipitation at the study site was estimated based on data from 8
local meteorological stations from 1936 – 2014. The rainfall dataset was obtained from the
National Brazilian Meteorological Institute (Instituto Nacional de Meteorologia - INMET)
website (www.inmet.gov.br) and from the Agência Nacional de Água (ANA) website
(www.ana.gov.br). As each of these records are discontinuous, we applied a regional vector
following the Brunet-Moret method using the software HYDRACCESS 1 . This method, developed
by the French Institute of Research for the Development (IRD), consists in the construction of a
fictive station which takes into account the gap of the records and calculates an annual index
exerting a mean value equal to 1 throughout the record (Figure S1).
